content.webTitle: The Merry Wives review – carry on, Falstaff

fields.headline: The Merry Wives review – carry on, Falstaff
fields.bodyText: Not even Shakespeare seemed overfond of The Merry Wives of Windsor: having apparently spent no more than a fortnight knocking off this all-prose potboiler at the behest of Elizabeth I, who couldn’t get enough of Falstaff and commanded a sequel to the Henry IV plays showing the fat knight in love. Barrie Rutter, however, is unusually partial to the piece, having already produced it twice before in Northern Broadsides’ 25-year history. Not inappropriately, Rutter’s gluttony for punishment now matches Falstaff’s own: “This is the third time,” he wails, having been dunked in a laundry basket, dressed as a woman and gulled into wandering round the forest with a pair of antlers on his head: “I hope good luck lies in odd numbers.” Over time, Rutter’s Falstaff has deepened in pathos, if not self-knowledge. He shambles around in a sorrowful state; a decrepit, rheumy figure whose bloated ego perfectly answers to Mistress Ford’s description of “a gross, watery pumpion”. But if the ebullience has slightly dimmed, perhaps it is not too fanciful to perceive Rutter’s performance as the farcical flip-side of his recent King Lear as another unsparing image of elderly self-delusion. The production is given a broadly 1920s feel and, wherever we are, it’s nowhere near Windsor (which has been erased from the title); with the flat caps and hard vowels suggesting northern moors rather than southern forests. The comedy arises from a salacious strain of English smut that would find its ultimate expression in the Carry On films, and at times comes a little too close for comfort. Andrew Vincent’s apoplectically jealous Ford is so determined to eject Falstaff from the linen basket that the front few rows find items of soiled underwear raining down on their heads. Who knows if Rutter will play the fat knight a fourth time? If not, we’ll still have pants for the memory. At the New Vic, Newcastle-under-Lyme, until 27 February. Box office: 01782 717962. Then touring
